In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is the solution in Julia:

```julia
function wrap_string(s::String; text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(s, " ")
    lines = String[]
    line = ""
    
    for word in words
        if length(line * " $word") > text_width
            push!(lines, line)
            line = "$word"
        elseif isempty(line)
            line = "$word"
        else
            line *= " $word"
        end
    end
    
    push!(lines, line) # add the last line
    
    return join(lines, "\n")
end

# example usage:
s = "This is a very long string that needs to be wrapped so it doesn't exceed the maximum text width. This function should handle this scenario perfectly."
println(wrap_string(s))
```

This `wrap_string` function works by first splitting the input string into individual words. It then iterates over each word, adding them one at a time to a new line (`line`). If the combined length of `line` and the current word exceeds `text_width`, it pushes `line` onto the `lines` array (which will hold all lines), clears `line`, and starts again. If `line` is empty, it just adds the current word to `line`.

At the end of the loop, it needs to add whatever's left in `line` to the `lines` array, since it didn't get added when length was exceeded. So it pushes `line` onto the `lines` array again (which will hold all lines). 

Finally, it joins all of the individual lines with newline characters (`"\n"`) and returns that string.

In this example usage, if you run `wrap_string(s)`, it should print out each line of the input string on a new line, wrapping them so that no one line exceeds 10 characters in length (the default `text_width`).
